data.title: 100 Days of Horror: 2020! Master Post!
data.meta_description: Welcome back horror-loving citizens of City of Geek! We can't believe it's been 265 (266? 264? data.text:
Welcome back horror-loving citizens of City of Geek!

We can‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs been 265 (266? 264? Freakin‚Äô leap years) since Halloween 2019 and the end of last year‚Äôs 100 Days of Horror Challenge! Is it really time to do it all again?

IT SURE IS! Buckle up, boneheads ‚Äì it‚Äôs time to go for a ride.

A ride of 100 new horror films for each participant! That includes YOU if you want!

This project is our own Kim Douthit‚Äôs long running challenge and the rest of us are joining her as we‚Äôve done the last few years! The gist: watch 100 new-to-you Horror films between July 23rd and October 30th (leaving Halloween open for your favorites!) Parameters are loose ‚Äì you want to include TV, go for it (Bob does, counting a season as one), watch a few favorites as Amy did last year, hop in as you can like Tony (he‚Äôs still in 2016 on this end!). Hell, Evan Peterson counts books! He‚Äôs a published author (buy his books!)

This page is the repository of what people post on the Facebook group for 100 Days of Horror. Whatever participants post over there, I‚Äôll copy/paste here (unless you don‚Äôt want me to, let me know if you don‚Äôt). As posts can shift based upon comments and all that, this page creates a direct record. It goes newest to oldest, so many of the writer‚Äôs comments may reference something further below.

I apologize for any weird formatting, the copy/pasting from Facebook doesn‚Äôt always translate to this awful block format WordPress moved to. I try to fix it as I can, but doesn‚Äôt always go. Thus, each entry may look different.

Check out last year here.

**NOTE FROM SEPT 12TH until this note is gone.**- I, Bob have become very behind on updating from the Facebook to here. Working on it now! Might take a day or two to get fully there.

Sept 19 ‚Äì Dasy 59 ‚Äì 42 Days to Halloween

BOB: PORNO (2020, Hoopla)

Yes, Hoopla. So you can watch porno through your library card! But I‚Äôm going to recommend you don‚Äôt. Our story: In 1992, 5 theatre employees find a hidden auditorium and storage room in the basement of their small theatre (2 working screens) after a naked vagrant breaks in. They find, among the ashes of the burned out storage room, a reel with some weird symbols on it. In a visual version of reading the Latin, they spool up the film. No surprise, it‚Äôs cursed, unleashing a busty succubus into the building.

It‚Äôs almost good, or even decent. Cursed film fucking with reality ‚Äì good stuff; I like that stuff. Characters are alright, a little lightly written but could have been worse ‚Äì while they are overly Christian, they were realistically so; not a Bible-thumping we see in many other films. Only the straight-edge projectionist is made for easily laughs.

But it DRAGS. At 98 minutes it‚Äôs very stretched. This is one where they characters KNOW they are in danger, but continually go off on side-quests, go into different rooms alone because they argued over something, or the like. There is SOME gore but not much ‚Äì the blurbs I saw befor watching kept saying ‚Äúgooey and gory horror-comedy!‚Äù I might have a different definition over gory. There is a bunch at the END but saying ‚Äúgrossly gory‚Äù to me indicates a higher amount.

A rewrite and 25 minutes shorter, and we‚Äôd have something. This probably would b ea good short, but at 98 minutes I kept pausing to see how much longer we had. It was a LONG 98 minutes.

Sept 18 ‚Äì Day 58 ‚Äì 43 Days to Halloween

BOB: HELLRAISER: REVELATIONS (2011, Tubi)

Finally caught the 2011 ‚Äúwe gotta make this in 3 weeks to keep the rights‚Äù Hellraiser sequel. Now, I‚Äôll admit ‚Äì I mostly like the other DTV sequels. Not perfect, but there is something about them that land. This‚Ä¶ this‚Ä¶. I‚Äôm convinced this is what Pinhead would show Clive Barker if he actually opened the box. Cheap cheap cheap. Filmed in what is likely a producer‚Äôs McMansion and what must be a set of shipping crates in his backyard he uses for less nefarious purposes than a crap Hellraiser sequel. Our story finds two asshole rich kids heading to Stereotype Mexico to be douches to everyone they meet. The get the box and open it, to meet really committed Pinhead cosplayer. Holy shit, this dude has no screen presence, no menace (I‚Äôm not a ‚Äúnot Doug Bradley so therefore sucks‚Äù guy, while no one will beat Bradley, but in a few days I‚Äôll be talking about Judgement and that guy did a good job). He looks very uncomfortable, and his Pinhead make is just awful. (In a positive note, the special effects make up is pretty alright. Nothing wowing but at least they tried there). Douche bros go missing and we cut to their families trying to get over the missing boys. They bicker over secrets and blame and it turns out the mom of one of them has a tape of what happened and the Box. One of them opens it and Pinhead, and the boys show up ‚Äì one as a cenobite that looks like a halfassed version of Pinhead (or a quarter assed as pinhead here is a half assed pinhead) and one whole but fucked up. The homeless guy who keeps the box in the real-world appears to do some murdering too as well. Sure why not?

Hellraiser Revelation is a cheap facsimile of a Hellrasier sequel, coming off as a slipshod amateur take on the franchise.

JAMES: Driven 2020 (prime)

I wanted to watch this because it had Richard Speight, Jr. in it as he was hunting down demons because of a family curse as he is being driven around by a cab driver who teams up with him. Most of the movie is in the car as they exchange banter back and forth throughout the movie and little demon action as it‚Äôs more of a comedy than horror. It‚Äôs still entertaining to watch the action in the cab than outside.

Sept 17 ‚Äì Day 57 ‚Äì 44 days to Halloween

KIM: FROGS

Another one I have never seen all the way through. Thoughts upon finishing this.

1. For a film called #Frogs there sure were a lot of other reptiles and amphibians.

2. I fully support all of the action taken by all the animals in this film.

3. Damn, Sam Elliott looks good at all ages.

BOB:

Hat man: Documented Cases of Pure Evil (2020, Prime)

Gave this documentary a go as June and Wendy talk to the director in an episode of Mystic Moon Cafe podcast about a year ago ‚Äì I know you‚Äôre both on here. I‚Äôm very behind! I promise to get caught up one day!

Anyway, Hat Man is a documentary featuring stories of people giving their reports of the shadow entity many people see: a very tall mass of black, shaped like a person and wearing a hat with an obvious brim.

As an episode of a supernatural TV show, it would be almost solid stuff. It‚Äôs alright, but nothing all that special. I think I would have liked it more if it were shorter, but gotta make it feature length right?

It was well made with care put into the methods and recreations. I particularly loved the design of the ghost itself in those recreations, a good job was done to create an unearthly darkness and it didn‚Äôt come off cheesy.

But there are a variety of issues that keep Hat Man from working. First is in repetition. Not in the familiarity of the stories ‚Äì that helps to show the same thing happening to various people to possibly give some sort of credence (though as is the case for documentaries like this, we‚Äôre speaking to the choir).But in the same people saying the same things. If I had to hear that same woman say ‚ÄúI think he‚Äôs Lucifer in the flesh‚Äù again‚Ä¶ First two times it was repeated I thought I had clicked back to earlier by accident. But no, the same audio clip is used again.

And many of the stories, while connecting to one other, and match my own read about/experienced by myself or trusted others encounters (I‚Äôll put my story below), can be explained away with a few more questions. I honestly believe many of them were simple sleep paralysis ‚Äì which is lampshaded a few times. Several others could be just tricks of the light (the photos presented for sure). And in sticking to a small selection of storytellers, we get an issue I‚Äôve seen in investigations I‚Äôve done and read of, reddit stories, podcasts (MMC and others) and similar documentaries ‚Äì the longer you have attention on someone telling a story, the wilder it‚Äôll get. I don‚Äôt believe anyone is activity trying to pull wool over another‚Äôs eyes (those people are usually pretty easy to spot) but ‚Äúoh the light is still on.. Maybe this stretches to the topic..‚Äù and embellishment occurs. Especially notable when a few subjects say ‚Äúbetween our last conversion and today I remembered [x] or [big thing] happened.‚Äù Giving that time allows practically begs ‚ÄúI need something bigger next time‚Äù in what should be a single day interview.

Final note: the font size on the on screen text was miniscule. Hard as hell to read.

PS for a great, and freakin‚Äô terrifying, documentary on sleep paralysis, check out The Nightmare.

PPS My hat man story. Not my house, but an ex from 2004. The first time I walked into her house, major heebie-jeebies. Not knowing if she had interest in the supernatural, I didn‚Äôt say anything but it had that feel. We‚Äôre hanging out watching a movie, and I see clearly on the 2nd level a tall jetblack shadow with a top hat appearing and walk down the hall (is it a hall if one side is open to the first floor via balcony?). She noticed I reacted to something. Before I can say anything she said ‚Äútall figure in a top hat?‚Äù Yup. She‚Äôd see him often day and night, and would wake her up once a month or so (though I take most ‚ÄúI woke up to a ghost‚Äù stories with salt as could be sleep mixing with reality). There was also a room of the house I received VERY negative feelings from, she did as well. No reason, but then again I never went in there, but I couldn‚Äôt help but keep looking at it.

ROBIN: PUPPET MASTER 5 (1994) Ok, I actually really enjoyed this one. I loved how the protagonist interacts with the puppets and I still really like when they‚Äôre the good guys. So far I think this one is right up there at my second favorite after the original.

JAMES: Infection 2019/2020 (prime)

A father has to fight a hundreds of infected people across Venezuela and find his son in this fast running zombie movie. Nothing original, but it‚Äôs a good watch with decent looking infected people.

Sept 16 ‚Äì Day 56 ‚Äì 45 Days to Halloween

KIM: Honeymoon From Hell (The Legend of Alice Flagg)

I don‚Äôt know why I keep watching Lifetime movies expecting them to be good. It‚Äôs my own fault really.

BOB: DEMONS 2 (1986, Prime)

You know how hugely crazy-go-nuts the first Demons was when the sequel is half as crazy-go-nuts and it‚Äôs still wilder than most similar movies. I‚Äôm not throwing shade at Demons 2. I loved it. Just know it‚Äôs more restrained than a helicopter crashing through he roof of a theater filled with zombie-demons (be honest, the creates are zombies with a demon make up). Now set in a 10 story apartment building, the demon invasion is started when ‚Äì because who needs Italian gonzo gore flicks to make sense- a demon from a movie pushes its way through a television set (someone saw Videodrome didn‚Äôt they?) and infects a young woman on her birthday. Chaos and bloodshed ensue as the demons try to kill a pregnant woman and her husband, a gym filled with oiled up strong men in banana-hammocks (led by the guy playing the Pimp in Demons!), a kid left alone, and a whole bunch of bloodbags ready for tearing into. It‚Äôs a crazy trip through anything goes filmmaking.

ROBIN: Mountaintop Motel Massacre (1983). This VHS cover is synonymous with browsing the video store for me. I can remember it sitting on the shelf in almost every horror section. The movie sadly isn‚Äôt that great, but I‚Äôm glad I finally watched it.

JAMES:

Circle 2015 (Netflix) I watched this with my sister today and it‚Äôs amazing how this movie reflects certain situations today. Messed up movie about how humans pick others to die. That‚Äôs all I‚Äôm going to say about that other than it‚Äôs a good movie but the ending was kinda now what.

Sept 15- Day 55- 46 Days to Halloween

KIM: The Bridge Curse

Where I did enjoy the mixture of found footage and traditional footage, this is a movie I have seen many many times before.

BOB: GRIZZLY II: THE REVENGE (1983/2020; Screener)

How to property rate this? So Grizzly II was mostly shot in 1983 until Hungary took all the camera equipment for failure TO pay bills so much of the connective tissue and Grizzly parts of Grizzly II are missing ‚Äì the animatronic didn‚Äôt quite work so barely (heh) shot before it shut down. In 1988 Cannon bought the rights to finish it but nothing went anywhere it was lost. A work print showed up in 2007, and this year a filmmaker said he ‚Äúfinished‚Äù the film. Maybe he did and added back in more, but the version I saw was the screener sent to Crypticon Filmfestival and it‚Äôs 1h13 min. A look around the internet shows a longer cut with a few more Louise Fletcher scenes is around with about 1h37. Maybe that‚Äôll fix some of the connection issues ‚Äì characters, especially the bear at the end, make big jumps of where they are and what has happened. Especially at the climax (sorry, spoilers I guess though we all know the bear attacking the giant concert in a national park will be the climax. BTW the basic plot is Fletcher wants to hold a massive concert in a US National Park but a 20 foot bear is killing people. Like the Mayor in jaws she won‚Äôt listen to the ranger and cares more for her upward mobility in hoping a Senator will like it). Bear attacks John Ryhs-Davies and others backstage, hero sees a ‚Äúhigh voltage sign‚Äù and next shot is the bear all mixed into the backdrop bloody and dead. Someone asks Fletcher is it part of the show and she says ‚Äúyes it is‚Äù. The end. How the bear moved 50 yards and got tangled in‚Ä¶ we do‚Äôt see it.

Can‚Äôt say it‚Äôs just 1983 footage, for like John Russo‚Äôs infamous 1998 cut of Night of the Living Dead, incongruous modern shots are mixed into the film. Oh boy do they not match. Clear drone HD shots of the forest, bad CG of a hunter shooting a confused bear, and weirdest of all ‚Äì modern concert footage Strangely, editing cochella into Grizzly II KINDA matches, as the original footage seems to be several concerts edited together already. It‚Äôs both a hard rock (filmed a Nazatheth concert), new wave, and some random Hungarian rock bands. And one modern Hungarian band that really doesn‚Äôt fit. Weird to cut from an excited real rock concert crowd, to a for-the-movie confused Hungarian extras concert to Cochella.

And yes I did say Louise Fletcher and John Ryhs-Davis further up there. THis is a nice cast for a cheapie filmed in the woods of Hungary in 1983. Can‚Äôt write it off as a vacation ‚Äì I mean who chooses to go to Hungary during the Cold war? But those stars are there! Charlie Cyphers from Halloween I and II is on hand a s grizzled drunk hunter.More interesting is the just about to bloom stars: Debbie Forman gets the most amount of time as the daughter of our hero but George Clooney, Laura Dern, and Charlie Sheen are the opening (off-screen) kills! So strange to have the three of them around for 4 minutes!

That is a lot more words than I expected to write about Grizzly II. Even if completed and released in 1983, it wouldn‚Äôt be all that good. The bear when we do see it, is obviously standing in place with the same sound effects, the characters are annoying, and it‚Äôs just structurally unwell and badly filmed.Maybe seeing the full version will fix it, but I doubt it.

ROBIN: Freddy‚Äôs Dead: The Final Nightmare (1991). I swore I‚Äôd finished the series off last year, but a recent trivia question made me realize I‚Äôd missed this one. This is going to be a random thoughts posting:

‚Äì Cameos galore! (Rosanne & Tom Arnold! Johnny Depp! Alice Cooper!)

‚Äì Aww! Baby Breckin Meyer!

‚Äì So. Many. References.

‚Äì Ugh, the video game sequence.

‚Äì This is like the Looney Toons of NOES movies.

‚Äì The second half of the movie is MUCH better than the first half.

I remember as a kid (I would have been 10), my sister went to see this in the theater and kept the pair of 3D glasses on her shelf until she moved out. I made her tell me how they killed Freddy.

JAMES: LOST BAYOU (2019, Rental)

More drama than anything, a struggling addict visits her estranged faith healing father on his houseboat on the bayous of Louisiana to reconnect. There she agrees to help bury a woman, who he thinks is his dead wife in a wonderful, gloomy tale of love and grief.

Sept 14- Day 54 ‚Äì 47 days to Halloween

KIM: THE ISLAND OF LOST SOUL

I spent the whole movie waiting for Marlon Brando to show up.

BOB: THE HUNT (2020, Netflix Disc)

The third version of THE MOST DANGEROUS GAME I‚Äôve watched this year! (it was the first of them to come out though).

Solid entry into the year ‚Äì though honestly I wanted more of hunting in The Hunt. Even with unexpected (and welcome) diversions, it‚Äôs pretty straightforward in much of it. Not much of the cat-and-mouse I like in these flicks.

I don‚Äôt know why the right was so upset about the movie ‚Äì sure the liberal elite are hunting MAGAs, but the film is far kinder to the MAGAs. Kneejerk in their distain. Heck, the way the left is treated is just about parody with not much that rips on the right, to be honest.

Betty Gilpin continues her awesome run of roles, killing it as our nearly silent, pragmatic and pissed-off lead.

And fuck yes, that final fight (no details other than that!) is one of my recent favorites.

Lots of humor, lots of blood, and a killer go from Gilpin, The Hunt is good stuff.

ROBIN: TERROR TRAIN (1980) Another classic slasher that I‚Äôve missed up until this point. Very effective! Man, that poor conductor. I will say that I completely missed that the magician is David Copperfield. I blame it on the lack of 80s mullet. Glad I finally caught this one!

JOHN: Gates of Darkness 2019 (prime)

I wanted to like this because of the cast but didn‚Äôt quite get there. Seemed to be missing something/plot and supposedly based on true events as a sister thinks her twin brother is possessed and asks the church for help only to unlock secrets from the past.

Sept 13 ‚Äì Day 53 ‚Äì 48 Days to Halloween

KIM: THE CRAZIES (1973)

This has been on my list forever. Enjoyable enough but I actually felt like it was a bit of a wasted opportunity. Given the current climate though, it still packed a punch.

BOB: BEHIND YOU (2020, Hulu)

A standard haunted mirror/Bloody Mary story. Two girls move into their aunt‚Äôs house after their mom dies; their dad is overseas and can‚Äôt be found. Another aunt died there as a kid, or vanished? The backstory is really muddled, along with the characters themselves. Actions, feelings, and reasons shift a good deal, along with the whys and hows.There is a knowledge shift to explain some of this but doesn‚Äôt feel right. Bad performances don‚Äôt help. Not really worth your time.

JAMES: FANGED UP (2020, Prime)

I wanted to watch this British horror/comedy because some of the actors in it and the premise of the prisoners in jail as food for vampire guards. It was stupidly funny at times and definitely had WTF moments. It‚Äôs not the best but it was entertaining and I‚Äôve seen a lot worse.

ROBIN: CURTAINS (1983). I surprisingly liked this despite the mack truck sized plot holes. Was happy to see it streaming on Amazon even though the transfer isn‚Äôt good. I‚Äôm with every review I‚Äôve ever seen for this‚Ä¶ The mask is amazing!

Sept 12 ‚Äì Day 52 ‚Äì 49 Days to Halloween

KIM: NIGHTMARE CASTLE

I was convinced I‚Äôd seen this, but apparently I had not. Solid watch. Worth it for Barbara Steele alone.

BOB: C.H.U.D II: BUD THE CHUD (1989, Tubi)

Chud II is less a sequel to CHUD than it is a bad remake of Night of the Creeps.

While I didn‚Äôt give the highest praise to CHUD, it is far and away better than CHUD II. Holy shit, is this a different movie. In tone, quality, make-up, and everything. Don‚Äôt expect to see anything resembling CHUD in CHUD II ‚Äì like Troll to Troll 2. At least Gerrit Graham (BEEF! From Phantom of he Paradise and a zillion other things‚Ä¶ character actors!) gets to mug it up as the titular character. He‚Äôs a soldier part of the CHUD project, an attempt to create zombie soldier as part of an inane poorly thought government plan headed up by a mortgage-payment-needed Robert Vaughn.

It‚Äôs infuriating how little care went into making this work. It‚Äôs just inane. Like take this: sometime late at night our ‚Äúheroes‚Äù steal the frozen Bud from a ‚Äúsecret‚Äù government facility (very easily, to replace a body they lost from their high school science lab). They hide him in a bathrooms at one‚Äôs parents home. In the course of a minute, a pre-teen is told to go back to bed, the mom says she is ready to get in her bath and then the parents say it‚Äôs time for dinner. Three separate moments to create three separate moments of a joke not landing. No joke really lands at all. The humor, direction and performances are all lacking in energy. Just listlessly moves through

If perhaps the gore or make-up was bigger and better I could see past the bad everything else. But the make-up is merely a layer of community theatre sick make up with bad teeth. Only a few drops blood to be seen. Just go nuts- bring on the goo and bloodspray!

Bud the Chud is a bad hororor comedy that thinks it‚Äôs funnier than it is with low-energy everything and massively annoying inconsistencies (that I shouldn‚Äôt be mad about, they didn‚Äôt care, why should I).

PS Okay the pool full of frozen zombies and the results are pretty cool, but too little too late

PPS ‚Äì there are no CHUDs like the one in first movie or in the poster. Very annoying. Nothing in the sewer either.

JAMES: Alive (2020, Netflix)

I don‚Äôt mind reading subtitles or you can change the language under settings but Alive is a fast paced Korean zombie movie. Some of the choices the main guy makes seem dumb but I still was rooting for him along with the girl across the way. Still an intense and entertaining movie.

ROBIN: WE HAVE ALWAYS LIVED IN THE CASTLE (2019)

I‚Äôve never read the book, but feel like I need to now. I enjoyed this one a lot. First thing I‚Äôve seen with Crispin Glover in quite some time. Also, I can‚Äôt get over how much Taissa Farmiga looks like her sister. Solid group of actors playing the main roles.

Sept 11 ‚Äì Day 51 ‚Äì 50 Days to Halloween ‚Äî HALFWAY THERE!

Kim: You Can‚Äôt Kill Stephen King

I really wanted to like this. I tried. And it has some‚Ä¶moments‚Ä¶but overall just a disappointing. Felt too long even though it was only 82 minutes. Would have been better served as a short.

BOB: JU-ON: ORIGINS (2020, 6 episode TV on Netflix)

Eh. It‚Äôs Ju-on, a series i‚Äôm meh on anyway (and I‚Äôve seen them ALL). Some moments that work, but a whole lot of annoyingly inconsistent filler and scares. Somehow at 3 hours it‚Äôs the most amount of Ju-On but also does the absolute least. Expect the standard Ju-On stuff, except dont‚Äô expect the scares and kill sequences ‚Äì our familiar ghosts dont‚Äô show up (outside maybe a moment).

All and all, I don‚Äôt really see the point in this entry. Weird to think the lackluster American one from January would be far better than a new Japanese one.

ROBIN: Amsterdamned (1988). Solid light slasher/detective story. I needed something simple & good and this fit the bill perfectly. I love that it even has a theme song over the closing credits.

JAMES: Open 24 Hours 2018 (rental)

A young woman recently released from prison gets a job at a 24 hour gas station on the advise of her parole officer. There she has hallucinations dealing with her past when she set her serial killer ex boyfriend on fire. As she deals with what‚Äôs real and not real, the suspense builds to a bloody, entertaining fight. Though the ending, I think could have been better.

Sept 10 -Day 50 ‚Äì 51 Days to Halloween

Kim: Witch-Hunt (2017)

I watched this on the recommendation of Jennifer Lovely and I very much enjoyed it! Very pleasant surprise! Also made me really want to play the card game they‚Äôre playing‚Ä¶

BOB: AFTER MIDNIGHT (2020, Hoopa/Kanopy)

A let down, bearing who is behind this flick. Early last decade Jeremy Gardner made the excellent THE BATTERY for $7000 and a hell of a lot of ingenuity. Now working with Aaron Moorehead & Justin Benson, the guys behind SPRING, and THE ENDLESS ‚Äì who also get a hell of a lot out of a little, Gardner gives an often dull, overly talky and meandering look at depression and being stuck in a rut by way of an occasional monster. Monster movies are often metaphor, and I don‚Äôt mind long explorations of personal demons, but this didn‚Äôt click. I think Gardner had a couple ideas of where to take it and what is about but really couldn‚Äôt hone down before it came time to roll. It was time to go, and the nut wasn‚Äôt cracked, giving an uneven but well acted film. I didn‚Äôt dislike it, but didn‚Äôt really like either. Frustating as it feels there is a better movie just out of reach.

But holy shit, go watch THE BATTERY. it‚Äôs on Prime and Tubi and it‚Äôs astounding. (Thanks Jennifer Lovely for the many recs to see it). SPRING is on Shudder and Tubi and THE ENDLESS is on Netflix and Hoopla. See those.

ROBIN: BABYSITTER KILLER QUEEN (2020, NETFLIX)

Not in the same league as the first one, sadly. One good thing‚Ä¶ 110% more Chris Wylde. (I think I‚Äôm one of like 10 people who loved his show back in 2001). Sequels are hard to get right.

James: The Babysitter Killer Queen 2020 (Netflix)

Everybody‚Äôs saying if you liked the first one, you‚Äôll like the sequel. It did not disappoint. Two years later every one thinks Cole is crazy after the events of the first movie and he‚Äôs dealing with them and seeing a therapist. He‚Äôs goes to the lake with friends and then all hell breaks loose when the demon, blood cult comes back to life and back for his blood. Killer Queen is crazier, bloody, fun entertainment that will rock to the end with all the movie references and killer soundtrack. Hope you enjoy it like I did.

Sept 9 ‚Äì Day 49 ‚Äì 52 Days to Halloween

KIM: BLOOD CULT (1985)

So, weirdly the title of this movie also seems to be ‚ÄúSlasher‚Äù but most of what I found was under ‚ÄúBlood Cult.‚Äù It‚Äôs not good. It‚Äôs‚Ä¶remarkably bad‚Ä¶buuuuut it‚Äôs so bad it‚Äôs also kind of amazing? I sort of wish I had been live tweeting it.

BOB: GRIZZLY (1976, Tubi)

Jaws. But with a bear. And stupid. Not completely a copy/paste plot points but pretty damned close. Close enough it‚Äôs obvious JAWS was the influence. JAWS rip-offs can be damned entertaining, but ORCA this ain‚Äôt. Our leads are interchangeable mountain dudes, the thing is filmed so damned ugly, and the the mixture of real bear (which exudes zero menace due to the filming angles they had to use for safety) and costume bits do not match at all. Holy shit, that last bit gets some decent entertainment with how awkward it looks.

Animal death CW: one bear cub off screen and one horse decapitation (which is so badly shot I laughed too hard at) on screen.

ROBIN: HELLMASTER (1992)

I didn‚Äôt know this movie existed. I think that there‚Äôs good reason for that. Ugh. This was terrible. Wow

James: Forgotten

Sept 8 ‚Äì Day 48 ‚Äì 53 Days to Halloween

KIM: AMERICAN HAUNTING

This movie is an utter waste of some truly talented actors.

BOB: I‚ÄôM THINKING OF ENDING THINGS (2020, Netflix)

I want to rave over how much I love this film, but I will not want to spoil a damned thing. I came in knowing zero and all the better for it. My letterboxd for 2020 releases currently has 120 titles, and this sits comfortably at 5. That‚Äôs how much I loved it. I‚Äôll just say right now- a disturbing Lynchian nightmare with amazing performances including a career maker from Jesse Buckley. I loved her in Beast and Chernobyl (she was the pregnant wife of one of the first victims). Toni Collette and David Thewlis are on board too. That should be enough for anyone.

Want more details (with minor set-up general idea spoilers)? Read on!

Jesse Buckley and Jesse Plemons (Breaking Bad, Game Night) are on the way to meet her parents. They‚Äôve been dating seven weeks and she‚Äôs thinking of ending things. Thus begins a nightmare of meeting odd-parents and the sheer uncomfortably of a long road trip with someone you barely know, and jumping into a house and family with a long fractured history you know nothing about. It‚Äôs a weird situation to start with, but this is a Charlie Kauffmann movie ‚Äì so there is FAR MORE going on that basic uncomfortably.

We have a film that also touches into emotional intertia and the sickness of memory.

EVAN: ‚ÄúNOVEL OF THE BLACK SEAL‚Äù & ‚ÄúNOVEL OF THE WHITE POWDER‚Äù (Arthur Machen, 1895, from THE THREE IMPOSTORS anthology): I need to read Machen‚Äôs THREE IMPOSTORS in its entirety. Both of these stories involve body horror, though they make us wait for the squish and slime and degradation of the human form. These two short stories are often anthologized with THE GREAT GOD PAN, which is of course Machen‚Äôs masterpiece. Reading the two ‚ÄúNOVEL OF‚Äù stories, it‚Äôs clear where Lovecraft got a lot of his inspiration for stories like ‚ÄúTHE DUNWICH HORROR‚Äù and ‚ÄúCOOL AIR.‚Äù Machen, in turn, clearly stole unapologetically from Stephenson, as both of these stories involve memorable tropes (including an atavistic drug and an epilogue in the form of confessions) that Stephenson had used in THE STRANGE CASE OF DOCTOR JEKYLL AND MISTER HYDE only a few years earlier. I love finding that chain of inspiration (and outright theft) as we put these movies and stories in close proximity.

bob:

HP Lovecraft Film Festival; 130th Birthday online festival. Presented as an alternative to the not-happening this year for obvious reasons Providence festival, this 4 hour streaming version is also a preview for the 3 day festival in October (the one that would normally be in Portland).

The selection was, I think, about 13 titles (some based on Lovecraft, some from other horror authors like Poe, and some just in tone). I wrote down notes at the start and stopped after a while. Some were new, and some were culled from old titles including two from the first festival 20 years ago.

One, The Summoning, had our own Eric all over the credits (along with Kelly Young) woo hoo!

As the shorts go, I was honestly a thumb mostly up for them all. None wowed me but none were bad either. There was a focus on more serious titles (mostly, Faust was fun and silly ‚Äì and stop motion) and the first few were dour!

THE SECT/ La Setta aka The Devil‚Äôs Daughter aka Demons 4 (1991, Michele Soavi, Scarecrow Video)

This is one of the best art-horror films I‚Äôve ever seen. It‚Äôs slick, imaginative, and very, very weird. Images repeat in smart, calculated ways. Cowritten by Argento, It starts with a Satanic biker gang (led by a Charles Manson Jesus lookalike) murdering a family of hippies, then flash forward to present day. Then we get a filthy old mystery man with a filthy old mysterious parcel, a bug-cam up someone‚Äôs nostril, and one of the best dream sequences I‚Äôve ever seen. That‚Äôs the first half hour. If you wondered where Ari Aster got some of the ideas for HEREDITARY, he clearly stole shamelessly from this film. There are also Easter eggs for fans of Lovecraft, Cronenberg, HELLRAISER, and THE SHINING. Plus: Evil rabbits! Evil pelicans! Evil water! Evil shroud of Turin! Evil feathers! Evil clocks! Evil blue! Fun trivia: star Kelly Curtis is the daughter of Tony Curtis and Janet Leigh, which means she‚Äôs also Jamie Lee Curtis‚Äôs sister, which you can totally see in her face at times. Also, if you can get a version with spoken English plus English subtitles, there are some very interesting discrepancies between the two. Highly, highly recommended.

The Other Lamb is a quietly disturbing, beautifully shot film. Selah (Raffey Cassidy in a mesmerizing performance) is a young woman on he edge of puberty when the cult she has grown up within ‚Äì all women (wives) and girls (daughters, with the implication of becoming wives) with one man Shepherd (Michiel Huisman of Haunting of Hill House, Invitation) is forced to move. I appreciate the detail in setting up this commune and insular world. The hierarchy and lives of the women (and man) are allowed to be presented without obvious exposition and my wife and I enjoyed trying to suss out the whos and the hows.
